intro: Acaena adscendens var. pilosiscapa, commonly known as the hairy burr bush, is a shrub native to New Zealand. It is characterized by its dense, spiny growth habit and produces small, spherical fruits that are adapted for seed dispersal by animals. The plant has compound leaves with multiple pairs of oval-shaped leaflets. Its flowers are small and inconspicuous, typically appearing in clusters. The species is well adapted to coastal and subalpine environments, thriving in well-drained soils.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena adscendens var. pilosiscapa is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the South Island, particularly in the Canterbury and Otago regions. This plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as tussock grasslands and rocky outcrops. It is well adapted to the local climate and soil conditions of these areas. Its distribution is limited to specific ecological zones within New Zealand.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena adscendens var. pilosiscapa was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the European flora during the colonial period. This plant is commonly found in coastal and inland areas, particularly in disturbed soils. It has become naturalized and is now considered a weed in some regions. Its spread is facilitated by its ability to thrive in a variety of environmental conditions.
